header_summary: Spam attacks in the Bitcoin network are causing issues with inscriptions and fees. The proposed solution suggests adding a standardization option to address the problem. Concerns are raised about unconfirmed inputs in coinjoins and the need for Replace-By-Fee in package transactions. Front-running in a peer-to-peer marketplace is discussed, with suggestions to quote prices for market activity. The context also includes discussions on system architecture, privacy in the Lightning Network, and a new protocol for closing channels.

recent_posts.title: Concern about "Inscriptions".
recent_posts.summary:
- Inscriptions in the Bitcoin network cause spam attacks and embed in the witness.
- Taking action against inscriptions can prevent future attacks, while inaction may encourage them.
- Adding a standardization option instead of a soft fork allows the community to decide.

recent_posts.title: Denial of Service using Package Relay
recent_posts.summary:
- In an email, a user expressed concerns regarding acceptance of unconfirmed inputs in coinjoin transactions.
- The user mentioned the risk of the sender replacing unconfirmed transactions and invalidating the coinjoin.
- They also discussed the benefits of package relay and upcoming RBF proposals for coinjoin security and efficiency.

recent_posts.title: Civ Kit: A Peer-to-Peer Electronic Market System
recent_posts.summary:
- Front-running in peer-to-peer marketplaces involves capitalizing on advance knowledge of influential transactions.
- The concern is that the model resembles a brokerage rather than an exchange market structure.
- The CivKit architecture aims to provide a flexible framework for peer-to-peer marketplaces while addressing front-running concerns.

recent_posts.title: Blinded Paths Doom Scenario
recent_posts.summary:
- Blinded paths in the Lightning Network provide privacy benefits by encrypting specific routes.
- Using "compliant" nodes in payment routes could compromise sender privacy and decentralization.
- The discussion raises concerns about potential privacy risks and trade-offs with implementing blinded paths.

recent_posts.title: Equalizing Packet Size
recent_posts.summary:
- Uniform packet sizes in the Lightning Network mitigate the risk of content inference by eavesdroppers.
- BOLT8 tunnel encrypter objects can be extended to create buffer functionality for fixed-size packets.
- Implementing a self-flush timer enhances robustness and transforms potential bugs into performance issues.

recent_posts.title: option_simple_close for "unfailable" closing
recent_posts.summary:
- This pull request introduces a new protocol for closing a channel in the Lightning Network, addressing fee disagreement scenarios.
- The pull request consists of three commits, each outlining the changes made to specific files.
- The new protocol simplifies the closing process and removes older protocols, while providing detailed explanations.

active_posts.title: Standardisation of an unstructured taproot annex
active_posts.summary:
- The taproot annex is non-standard and discussions are underway for standardization using TLV format.
- In the meantime, developers can use a non-structured annex starting with '0' for immediate utilization.
- This approach allows for flexibility, efficiency, and a future transition to a structured format.

active_posts.title: Blinded 2-party Musig2
active_posts.summary:
- The discussion revolves around the implementation of 2-of-2 Schnorr Musig2 for statechains.
- Party 1 should remain blind to certain information such as the aggregate public key and message being signed.
- Blinded statechains rely on trusting the server's report of partial signatures and verifying them client-side.

active_posts.title: On the experiment of the Bitcoin Contracting Primitives WG and marking this community process "up for grabs"
active_posts.summary:
- Last year, a new community process was introduced to specify covenants and address consensus development issues.
- Various initiatives were undertaken, including the bitcoin-inquisition fork and the establishment of the Bitcoin Contracting Primitives Working Group.
- The author decided not to actively pursue the process further but encouraged others to continue their efforts.

active_posts.title: HTLC Endorsement for Jamming Mitigation
active_posts.summary:
- The email updates on channel jamming and shares details for the next call on May 1st.
- The group plans to gather data on HTLC endorsement and local reputation tracking for jamming mitigation.
- The email outlines goals for data gathering and proposes a reputation scheme for HTLC forwarding.

active_posts.title: Potential vulnerability in Lightning backends: BOLT-11 "payment hash" does not commit to payment!
active_posts.summary:
- The LNbits team found an exploit that allowed attackers to create fraudulent balances.
- The exploit has been fixed in LNbits version 0.10.5, and users are advised to update.
- Developers should be cautious of similar exploits in Lightning applications and use additional checks.
